content: Indonesian cake **Pandan cake** is a light, fluffy, green-coloured [sponge cake](/wiki/Sponge_cake) flavoured with the juices of *[Pandanus amaryllifolius](/wiki/Pandanus_amaryllifolius)* leaves. It is also known as pandan [chiffon](/wiki/Chiffon_cake). The cake is popular in [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia), [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), [Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnam), [Cambodia](/wiki/Cambodia), [Laos](/wiki/Laos), [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand), [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka), [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong), [China](/wiki/China), and also the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands). It is similar to the [buko pandan cake](/wiki/Buko_pandan_cake) of the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines), but differs in that it does not use coconut. ## Ingredients The cake shares common ingredients with other cakes, which includes flour, eggs, butter or margarine, and sugar. However, the distinct ingredient is the use of pandan leaf, which gives the cake its distinct green colouration. The cakes are light green in tone due to the [chlorophyll](/wiki/Chlorophyll) in the leaf juice. It sometimes contains green [food colouring](/wiki/Food_colouring) to further enhance its colouration. The cakes are not always made with the leaf juice, as they can be flavoured with *Pandanus* [extract](/wiki/Essential_oil), in which case colouring is only added if a green colouration is desired. The original pandan cake common in [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands), and [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) is a usually soft [sponge cake](/wiki/Sponge_cake) akin to the light and fluffy [chiffon cake](/wiki/Chiffon_cake), made without any additional coating or [frosting](/wiki/Icing_(food)). The other variants are actually derived from other cake recipes, with any similarity only in the usage of green pandan flavouring extract. ## History and origin In Southeast Asia, cake-making techniques were brought into the region through European colonization. [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and Singapore were [British possessions](/wiki/British_possessions), whilst [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia) was formerly a [Dutch colony](/wiki/Dutch_East_Indies). European colonists brought their cuisine along with them, with the most obvious impacts in bread, cake, and pastry-making techniques. In [Southeast Asian cuisine](/wiki/Southeast_Asian_cuisine), the [pandan leaf](/wiki/Pandan_leaf) is a favourite flavouring agent used to give off a pleasant aroma, and added to various dishes ranging from fragrant [coconut rice](/wiki/Coconut_rice), [traditional cakes](/wiki/Kue), to sweet desserts and drinks. It was the fusion of European cake-making techniques with locally grown ingredients that created the pandan-flavoured cake. In 2017 [CNN](/wiki/CNN) named the pandan cake as the national cake of Singapore and Malaysia. This has led to reactions in Indonesia that regarded the pandan cake, locally known as *kue bolu pandan,* as Indonesian. In Singapore pandan cake was popularised by one of the city's most popular bakeries, Bengawan Solo, a cake shop owned by a Singaporean citizen of [Indonesian](/wiki/Chinese_Indonesians) origin. According to CNN Indonesia, this cake originated from Indonesia, which can be traced to the cake-making techniques of Dutch colonists in the [Dutch East Indies](/wiki/Dutch_East_Indies) (now Indonesia). The colonial Dutch and [Indo](/wiki/Indo_people) peoples combined cake-making techniques from Europe with the available local ingredients like the pandan leaf as flavouring and colouring agents. This cake is also known as pandan cake in [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_language), and is quite popular in the Netherlands due to its historical link to Indonesia. Other than its use in chiffon pandan cake, pandan leaf is also used as green colouring and flavouring in the Dutch-Indonesian favourite pandan [spekkoek](/wiki/Spekkoek) or [lapis legit](/wiki/Lapis_legit) (layered cake), demonstrating the prominence of pandan leaf in Dutch-Indonesian cake and pastry making. ## Names in different languages - [Mandarin](/wiki/Standard_Chinese): 香蘭蛋糕; *xiānglán dàngāo* - [Malaysian](/wiki/Malaysian_language): *kek pandan* - [Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesian_language): *bolu pandan* - [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_language): pandan cake - [Khmer](/wiki/Khmer_language): *Num Sleok Touy* - [Vietnamese](/wiki/Vietnamese_language): *Bánh pho sĩ*code: vie promoted to code: vi , *bánh lá dứa*code: vie promoted to code: vi - [Cantonese](/wiki/Cantonese): 班蘭蛋糕; *baan1 laan4 daan6 gou1* - [Thai](/wiki/Thai_language): เค้กใบเตย *khêk bı tey* - Food portal - Indonesia portal - [Kue bolu](/wiki/Kue_bolu) - [Coconut cake](/wiki/Coconut_cake) - [Ube cake](/wiki/Ube_cake) - [Mango cake](/wiki/Mango_cake) - [Mamón](/wiki/Mam%C3%B3n)
